data.title: Test vscode.debug.DebugConfigurationProvider
data.body:
Test for #32086:

Complexity: 3

- [x] Windows - **@roblourens**
- [x] OS X - **@jrieken**
- [x] Linux - **@isidorn**

In this milestone we've created a "real" API replacement for the 'startSession' and 'initialConfigurations' commands that we are currently using.
This API is proposed and can be found [here](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/vscode.proposed.d.ts#L212-L251).
To use the proposed API copy the vscode.proposed.d.ts it in your extension folder.

Verify that this API works as documented:
- use the "hello world" extension
- register a `DebugConfigurationProvider` for a specific debug type.
- implement `provideDebugConfigurations` by returning a real (or fake) launch configuration. Verify that this is added to the initial launch.json that is created if a project folder has none. Make sure that the correct workspaceFolder is passed to `provideDebugConfigurations` in the 0,1,n-folder workspace configurations. 
- implement `resolveDebugConfiguration` by massaging the passed launch config and verify that it is passed to the correct debug adapter. Make sure that you can even change the `type` of the config so that another debug adapter is started. Make sure that the correct workspaceFolder is passed to `resolveDebugConfiguration` in the 0,1,n-folder workspace configurations.

data.title: QuickOpen (Ctrl+P) search matching logic needs to be improved

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10

If I have a file with path: `ui/src/ui/Icons/index.js`
and there are other files, such as: `ui/src/utils/constants.js`, etc...

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/760112/29767496-3be8a502-8c00-11e7-8af7-1b6c9affa80c.png)
after scrolling about 49 or so entries, I get the match I **need**:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/760112/29767534-65bafa06-8c00-11e7-9601-29e65226705a.png)

Then, searching for `ui/Icons` puts the more relevant `ui/src/ui/Icons` path somewhere way down the list, not what I'd expect. I'd expect a matches with longer *runs* to be higher rated, no? It seems like this was (partially) fixed somewhere in previous builds because I always type these kind of path and stopped getting miffed with the results - they were not *perfect*, but they were passable, But lately I'm finding myself getting miffed again, so I think this bug is a regression?

Maybe possibly linked: #20546

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Fix #33155: treat .pac file as javascript file
data.body:
#33155: treat .pac file as javascript file
Let vscode auto detect .pac file and use javascript editor to deal with it.

proxy-auto-configuration file is a kind of javascript file which browsers could use it to decide which proxy should use for certain url or ip.
Refer to this wiki for details.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proxy_auto-config

data.title: Open internal modules in preview tab
data.body:
- Debug a node script like this

```
eval('debugger;//123')
```

- When breaking in the eval'd script, leave the tab open in the editor
- Change the eval'd code in some way, e.g. change the comment
- Debug it a second time
- If the same number is assigned, e.g. `VM65` on both runs, the editor will open the old version of the script which is already open. It doesn't send a `scriptRequest` to the debug adapter to get the new script text. This leads to confusing situations when debugging eval code.

data.title: Some punctuation causes incorrect wrapping when followed by quote.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:05:38.342Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
htmltagwrap|bra|0.0.3
path-intellisense|chr|1.4.2
vscode-reveal|evi|0.0.9
mdmath|goe|2.0.3
word-count|hyp|0.1.1
mdhelper|jos|0.0.11
md-navigate|jri|0.0.1
vscode-simple-icons|Lau|1.5.3
markdown-shortcuts|mdi|0.8.1
csharp|ms-|1.12.1
mono-debug|ms-|0.15.7
wordcount|ms-|0.1.0
vscode-icons|rob|7.12.0
spellchecker|swy|1.2.13
markdown-all-in-one|yzh|0.8.3

(1 theme extensions excluded)


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create or open a file of any type compatible with VS Code that uses text, preferably .md or .txt but other file types work.
2. Insert text mixed with white space to ensure proper wrapping behavior.
3. At the end of the line, for the last character before wrapping would occur, insert a comma (`,`), a question mark (`?`), or an ampersand (`&`).
4. Follow that character with one of the above listed characters or with a double quotation mark (`"`) or single quotation mark (`'`) or a space (` `) with no other characters between.

Expected result: The entire chunk of punctuation wraps as though it were a single word.
Actual Result: The second punctuation mark wraps as though the previous mark was whitespace.

![wrapping](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31398891/29760298-480a0a4e-8b77-11e7-8fc9-0d39c3860c03.png)


This is particularly annoying when writing dialogue using markdown, as it causes the quotation mark to wrap and look odd.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: g++ build Task can't find files on WSL

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
python|don|0.7.0
cpptools|ms-|0.12.3



---
### Description 

Trying to set up simple g++ build Task using VS Code with WSL. I can use g++ to compile just fine in the terminal, but when I try to set this up using tasks it can't find the source files. I have posted to StackOverflow but no response.

For illustration here's the output when I try with a simple hello world C++ program. I've shown a simple build task as well as an ls to show that the file is there. Both of these tasks were run while my focus was on the source code file window.

> Executing task: g++ helloworld.cpp <
>g++: fatal error: no input files compilation terminated.
>Terminal will be reused by tasks, press any key to close it.

>Executing task: ls <
>helloworld.cpp
>Terminal will be reused by tasks, press any key to close it.



I have tried with the exact example task specified in [the documentation](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/languages/cpp) (converted to text for upload - [ tasks.txt](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/1255076/tasks.txt)) and some variants of this but no success. When I close the terminal created by the task and try to just build from the command line it works.

```
testvscpp$ ls
helloworld.cpp
testvscpp$ g++ helloworld.cpp
testvscpp$ ls
a.out helloworld.cpp
```

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use WSL bash shell as default (user settings). 
2. Create build task for g++.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Emmet - spaces in snippets
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: win7x64

If you would make mistake in writing your custom snippets and type space inside the snippet (property or value), like this:
```
  "html": {
    "snippets": {
      "test1": "test 111",    <----
      "test2": "test22222",
      "test3": "test33333333"
    }
  }
```

... it will not show this "crashed" snippet in the list, and if you will try to force it to expand - VS Code will notify you about the error:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24613274/29755818-6950a166-8ba6-11e7-86f0-8168d8e22c12.png)

well, I believe, that users deserve errors with more specific information (like `"Emmet -- Forbidden symbol ("space") in D:/files/snippets.json on line 83"`)... not just "something gone wrong in abbr."... that's ridiculous.

But more important in this case, that this "crashed" snippet also makes all other snippets with "test..." in it - disappear from the snippets list.

GIF:
![space in snippets](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24613274/29755950-08cd2344-8ba8-11e7-841e-976605036856.gif)

data.title: SCM: Allow setting default provider in settings
data.body:
It would be nice to configure the SCM provider (e.g. git, mercurial) to use by default when opening a previously unopened folder.

As it currently stands, VSCode 1.15 defaults to git for every folder opened, even if the folder contains a mercurial repository.

data.title: High CPU usage on renderer on Linux (maybe because of git features)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: Arch-Linux, kernel 4.12.8-2

Steps to Reproduce:
Just open and wait. It only occurs when I start typing. I suspect it is the autocomplete dropdown helper, due to the delay until it appears.

Edit 1: Also, it only happens on some files, for some reason. They all have the '.h' extension and have no more than 500 lines.

Edit 2: I decided to change to name of the file, and it no longer has this problem. Another thing I noticed is that the the git lines on the side (green and blue) take several seconds to appear (the file only has 100 lines) whereas in other files is almost instant. Perhaps something to do with the git visualisation, since the problem is on the renderer process.

Edit 3: I commited the changes and that file no longer has issues, so definitely something to do with git. Before the problems what I did was copy a folder I had to name+"2", and I started recoding on the file from the original folder. Somehow it messed up with git, perhaps because the diff could just be a rename (the code on the copied folder was kept the same) but then the original file was being modified as well. (In case you want to see the [commit](https://github.com/gmardau/gmd-tree-library/commit/6888f665f6155a6a910657fd1eb99b95f5718bce))

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

``ps aux | grep studio-code``
```
gustavo   4356  0.8  0.6 1595344 104956 ?      Ssl  23:33   0:01 /opt/visual-studio-code/code
gustavo   4359  0.0  0.1 350444 30464 ?        S    23:33   0:00 /opt/visual-studio-code/code --type=zygote --no-sandbox
gustavo   4380  0.5  0.4 461136 81224 ? data.title: Limit resource size to ensure resource inline
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: Insider
- OS Version: macOS

Our editor compile pipeline will merge CSS and inline resources (images) and the size limit is 5kb. As we added two large files, Monaco Editor shipped with a new contrib folder with two images which are over size limit.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/876920/29754184-0c3ad53a-8b35-11e7-915b-6a4377414b8a.png)

All other icons are merged into `editor.main.css`, let's optimize `String_16x.svg`.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

webfreak.code-d
wholroyd.jinja
wix.vscode-import-cost
zhuangtongfa.Material-theme
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. I'm unsure when this appeared, but I had installed Eslint extension and went to put the ESLint settings in my json.settings
2. At which point I noticed, when going back and forth testing my eslint configuration, this:

```
file: 'vscode://defaultsettings/settings.json'
severity: 'Warning'
message: '$ref '/definitions/jspmDefinition' in {1} can not be resolved.'
at: '1,1'
source: ''
```

I'm myself unsure whats happening here. When I load with no extensions, yes, it does not reproduce, but adding the extensions one by one doesn't seem to reproduce either. From what I can tell, when I actually double click on that error, it takes me to the settings.json  location in vscode:// and at the top and bottom of the file, above the curly braces, there is a opening bracket '[' and closing bracket ']' respectively. I imagine that’s whats throwing that error. I have attempted to try and just edit that file, and it appears I can't. I can't seem to find it either (For the record, I'm on a Mac, 10.12.6)

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: No

data.title: JSDoc for a chain assignment functions and objects don't work
data.body: - VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T17:15:57.756Z) - OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0 - Extensions: Extension|Author (truncated)|Version ---|---|--- EditorConfig|Edi|0.9.4 vscode-wakatime|Wak|1.1.13 vscode-icontheme-nomo-dark|be5|1.3.2 markdown-preview-github-styles|bie|0.0.2 vue-peek|dar|1.0.2 vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11 Go|luk|0.6.63 typescript-javascript-grammar|ms-|0.0.23 vetur|oct|0.9.5 vscode-spotify|shy|2.0.0 language-stylus|sys|1.7.3 (2 theme extensions excluded) --- Steps to Reproduce: 1. Write JSDoc to a chain assignment function or object; 2. JSDoc for a chain assignment functions and objects don't work. Screenshot The code i'd used ```js /** * Filter an iterable using a filter function. * @param {Iterable.} list * @param {function(T, number, T[]):boolean} filter * @template T * @returns {Array.} */ const all = exports.all = (list, filter) => [...list].filter(filter) ```
